intro: Pinus sylvestris var. lapponica, commonly known as the Scots pine, is a variant of the Scots pine native to northern Europe and parts of Asia. It is a coniferous evergreen tree that typically grows in boreal and subarctic regions. The plant has needle-like leaves that are typically 1–2 cm long and retain their color throughout the winter. Its cones are woody and often remain attached to the branches for several years. This variety is adapted to cold climates and is often found in open, windswept habitats.
